sources.data_found: NSF Award Abstract #1919616 (2019): 'MRI: Acquisition of a High Performance Computing Cluster... The instrument will consist of a head node, 3 login nodes, 44 compute nodes, 2 GPU nodes...'

Department of Computer Science page lists degrees: B.S. in Computer Science, M.S. in Computer Science. No Ph.D. in Computer Science listed (only Ph.D. in Earth/Ecosystem Science, Math, etc. in the college).
2022 Degrees Awarded: Computer Science (Bachelor's): 91; Computer Science (Master's): 59. (Used for enrollment estimation).

student_data.notes: Exact enrollment headcounts not published on department 'About' page. Counts estimated from DataUSA/IPEDS 2022 degree completion data. Undergraduate: 91 degrees awarded * 4.5 year avg duration ≈ 409 students. Graduate (MS): 59 degrees awarded * 2 year avg duration ≈ 118 students. PhD: CMU does not list a standalone Computer Science PhD program on the College of Science & Engineering website.

gpu_resources.notes: CMU HPC Cluster (funded by NSF MRI #1919616): Specification lists '2 GPU nodes'. Press releases identify the hardware as Dell PowerEdge (likely C4140 based on 2019 MRI timing/budget) with 'NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPUs'. Standard configuration for Dell GPU nodes in this class is 4x GPUs per node. Estimated Total: 2 nodes * 4 V100 = 8 V100 GPUs. No newer clusters (A100/H100) found in public documentation or newer NSF awards as of late 2024. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

analysis_notes: Central Michigan University is an R2 institution with a focused HPC resource funded by a 2019 NSF MRI grant. The cluster is relatively small (2 GPU nodes). No evidence of newer A100/H100 acquisitions found in public NSF award databases or IT news releases. CS PhD count is 0 as the university does not appear to offer a standalone CS doctorate.
